results.title: The Juggler of Notre Dame
results.brief_description: Animated adaptation of Anatole France’s story of a juggler named Barnaby who is given shelter in a monastery. To start with, the seemingly worthless Barnaby and his antics displease the monks, but one night his juggling causes a miracle, and the monks realise the worth of Barnaby and his talent. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: The Joycelin Shrager story
results.creator_credit: Barton Weiss, Mark Block and Kino Delux
results.brief_description: The filmed biography of Joycelin Shrager, a mythical, appallingly incompetent woman director, whose obsession with film pervades her whole existence.

results.title: The Joy of winter
results.creator_credit: Bernard Gosselin, Jean Dansereau, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: How Canadians adjust to their long, snowbound season. Filmed with humour, The Joy of Winter shows people making the best of what they cannot change. From tiny tots to human polar bears the film leaves no doubt that, in the eyes of many Canadians, winter may offer more attractions than summer. Film without words. (Awards: Gijon; Necochea.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bernard Gosselin, Jean Dansereau, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Joy of flying free
results.brief_description: Free flight model aeroplanes differ from all others because once they are set in motion, they are under no control from their builders. “The joy of flying free” touches on every aspect of free flight model aviation. It will introduce the novice to this fascinating hobby and delight the enthusiast.

results.title: The Joy Luck Club
results.creator_credit: Wayne Wang, Patrick Markey, Ronald Bass, Amy Tan and Hollywood Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on Amy Tan’s best-selling novel, “The Joy Luck Club” tells the story of two generations of Chinese women. Four are mothers and wives who emigrated from China to build new lives and families in the United States. The other four are their Chinese-American daughters who are struggling to define their own identities against the expectations of their mothers and the American society where they live. Wayne Wang masterfully interweaves the stories of the eight women which spans from feudal China to modern America, highlighting the similarities and differences between the two generations. “The Joy Luck Club” is a beautiful film to watch, with lavish production values which make the characters’ stories even more compelling.
